Musik am Dom zu Salzburg. Repertoire und liturgisch gebundene Praxis zwischen Hochbarocker Repräsentation und Mozart-Kult. Von Eva Neumayr, Lars E. Laubhold und Ernst Hintermaier. Schriftenreihe des Archivs der Erzdiözese Salzburg 18. Wien: Hollitzer Verlag, 2018.
Graphic Design and the Archive in the Community College Classroom.
summary: The “Museum Paper” is a central activity within any introductory Art History course, yet this assignment proves especially difficult for the History of Graphic Design. Little valued within the hierarchy of media, Graphic Design artworks rarely appear on museum walls, thus providing fewer opportunities for students to engage with the physical objects. These problems are compounded for community college students, who often have limited time outside of class in which to travel to a museum. However, rooting the assignment in a class trip to a museum archive allows community college students to view Graphic Design objects while also performing key research practices. This presentation will describe an assignment in which students produce research papers on Graphic Design objects selected from the collection of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. We travel as a class to the Museum’s Print Study Room, where they view their objects. Next, we visit the Museum Library and Archives to utilize their specialized resources and documentation. Modeled on my own research methodologies, the ultimate goal of this assignment is to encourage community college students to envision themselves as researchers from the earliest moments of their scholarly development.

title: Тасулас А., Потенциальное «яблоко раздора»: Кипр в советском внешнеполитическом анализе в 1946-1953 гг.
summary:
The article deals with the Soviet foreign policy analysis regarding Cyprus
from 1946 to 1953. The scientific novelty of the research is the study of the foreign policy of the USSR about the evolution of political events, in regard with Cyprus and the Eastern Mediterranean. The problem was analyzed on the basis of archival materials drawn from the Archives of the Foreign Policy of the Russian Federation (AVP RF). The purpose of the article is the thorough study of the Soviet analysis of Cyprus in the period 1946-1953. To examine the topic in detail, it was necessary to perform a number of tasks. First, to reveal how the question of the future of Cyprus became a subject of the Soviet Union's foreign policy; second, to examine the position of the Soviet Union on Enosis (unification) of the island with Greece; third, to explain the logic of the Soviet analysis and the contradictions of its competitors in a region of great geopolitical importance. The author has reviewed in detail the diplomatic correspondence sent from the Soviet Embassy in Greece, in order to conclude that Moscow analyzed in detail the political events around Cyprus even before its participation in the mid-50s. Along with this, the work also highlights the Kremlin's refusal to cooperate more closely with the Greek Communists during the Greek civil war.

title: AER Newsletter Summer 2020

title: The sacred grove: Lost essays by modern masters in the Listener
summary: Every issue of the Listener featured three pages of brief, unsigned book reviews – each no more than a few hundred words in length – in a section entitled “The Listener’s Book Chronicle”. By cross-checking the anonymous reviews in each issue against the corresponding payment in the ledger’s roster of contributors, it is possible to identify the reviews’ authors, some of whom were major figures on the 1930s literary scene. There are over forty pieces by Stephen Spender, twelve by Graham Greene, nine by Elizabeth Bowen, four by Louis MacNeice, one by Dylan Thomas and one by Stefan Zweig. These previously unattributed reviews are not noted in any of the extant bibliographies or checklists, and further consultations with scholars, literary executors, societies, authors’ trusts and archival collections (such as the British Library and the Bodleian) confirm their status as “new” works. I hope that a resurrection and critical examination of these neglected writings will soon be under way.

Setting the stage for Hittite Studies in Victorian England: practices and methods of the 1870s
summary: Durant les années 1870, on voit émerger en Angleterre des travaux portant sur les monuments de Syrie et d’Anatolie portant des inscriptions que l’on appelle alors Luwian or Anatolian Hieroglyphic. C’est l’époque des premières tentatives de déchiffrement de ces inscriptions, sous l’impulsion de G. Smith et A.H. Sayce. Par ailleurs, W. Wright et A.H. Sayce attribuent ces monuments aux Hittites. Le débat se développe au sein de diverses sociétés savantes, comme le British Museum, mais aussi plusieurs clubs, avec un mélange de coopération et de rivalité entre les principaux chercheurs. Le présent article propose la première vue d’ensemble d’une recherche en cours au départ d’archives inédites conservées à Londres, Cambridge et Oxford.

title: 'Monsters' in Manuscripts: Searching for the Imperfect in the Archives
summary:
In March of 2017, the Mütter Museum opened its second Library-curated exhibit, Imperfecta.  Using artifacts from The Historical Medical Library and Mütter Museum collections, Imperfecta examines the shifting perceptions about abnormal human development, from fear and wonder
to curiosity and clinical science. Faced with limited gallery space, the selection of Library materials on display is narrowed to rare books, and only those few which had compelling images and which provided strong evidence of the shift in perception of monstrosities.  Through these books, one can examine some of the ‘major,’ or popular, literature surrounding monstrous births. But what did the local lay or professional practitioner have to say on the subject? To begin answering this question, I looked at some of our recipe books (dating from circa 1640 to 1766) and student lecture notes (dating from the 1780s, 1840s, and 1870s).

title: Workshop at The Keep, Sussex - Opening up the Archive

This workshop outines the archival research undertaken for the May Sinclair Scholarly Editions project, drawing on Sinclair's draft manuscripts in The Keep archives. Drawing mainly on the short fiction arm of the project, MSS variants are compared, with particular emphasis on Sinclair's meticulous revisions to passages of text referring to symbolism and sublimation. The workshop also draws upon the illustrations to the Uncanny Stories volume by the Belgian artist, Jean de Bosschere.

All De Bosschere images are used with the kind permission of Alain Bilot.

title: Eight years following the traces of Giuseppe and Amalia Nizzoli: preliminary results of the Nizzoli Project (2008-2016)
summary:
The Chancellor of the Austrian Consulate in Egypt, Giuseppe Nizzoli, and his wife Amalia Sola represent two prominent personalities who contributed much to the history of Egyptology: they sold a remarkable number of Egyptian collections and left an important book of memories of those years in Egypt. Nevertheless, they are frequently neglected in Egyptological studies and several aspects of their life are still unclear. 

In 2008, the authors started a long-term project to re-investigate of these two persons, following their footsteps through Italy as well as across Europe. The paper will present the preliminary results of this project, showing important details concerning both their professional and private lives.

title: Re-educating teachers: ways and consequences of Sovietization in Estonia and Latvia (1940–1960) from the biographical perspective.
summary: This article is based on a comparative analysis, juxtaposing archival and oral historical sources, and gives a focus to the changes that took place in the teaching profession's in annexed Baltic States. Particular attention was paid to the first generation of Estonian and Latvian teachers who were trained as Soviet teachers. Born in the 1920s-30s, they grew up in the 1940s-50s and their reformation into ‘Soviet people’ involved not only adopting certain new qualities but also rejecting values that had long been seen as familiar and inherent. The core issues for this research were the ways different state strategies and factors exerted mutual influence in the process of re-educating teachers and how far teachers were reformed by the beginning of the 1960s. Similar coercive situations were also created in the Soviet sphere of influence of the Eastern bloc countries after World War II.

title: “‘Höchle zeichnete mir diesen Leichenzug’. Anton Gräffer, Johann Nepomuk Hoechle und die verschollene Zeichnung von Beethovens Begräbnisfeier,” in: Wiener Geschichtsblätter 58/4 (2003): 299-315.
Archival documents about the workshop of Jheronimus Bosch
summary:
By using the archival sources about Bosch a framework of facts about his life can be reconstructed. BoschDoc can be used to properly support theses about Jheronimus Bosch, his work and working environment. A case study is added to illustrate this. 
Keeping in mind the late medieval painting practice of masters, journeymen and apprentices working together in workshops, as well as the fact that Bosch came from a family that produced many generations of artists, it is likely at least some of those artists collaborated within a family workshop or multiple family workshops. What archival sources tell us about these family workshops is explicated in this paper. The premises Markt 29 and Markt 61 are covered and suggestions about the identity of possible coworkers of Bosch are made.

title: "Undergraduate Research in Writing Studies: Using the DALN to Stimulate Intellectual Inquiry and Teach Research Methods"
summary: This article offers a model for an undergraduate research (UGR) assignment sequence that utilizes the DALN to stimulate intellectual inquiry, archival literacy, and interest in scholarly pursuits. I highlight an assignment sequence derived from an upper-level writing course I teach that introduces students to primary research methods and that enables them to engage in scholarly academic research where they can make scholarly contributions—from project design and data collection to coding, analyzing, and writing up findings. In this project, students draft an audio literacy narrative, present with a partner their rhetorical analysis of an artifact, write an exploratory-reflective essay, compose an academic research essay that utilizes literacy narratives in the DALN, draft a conference proposal, and give a poster presentation. By highlighting the DALN’s role in creating undergraduate writing scholars, I aim to show how faculty can use the DALN to promote UGR and stimulate intellectual inquiry while simultaneously adding value to student learning, undergraduate programs, and composition at-large. By highlighting the DALN’s role in creating undergraduate writing scholars, I aim to show how faculty can use primary sources to stimulate intellectual inquiry and promote UGR. I also discuss strengths and limitations of this approach.

title: “The Schober Family’s „tiefe sittliche Verdorbenheit“ as Revealed in Spy Reports from 1810 about Ludovica and Her Mother,” in: Schubert durch die Brille 29 (June 2002): 39-65.
Sources for Cole Porter's creativity
summary: Scholarly research into the nature of Cole Porter’s musicals and song-writing practice has encountered a number of limitations due to a lack of autograph music drafts. As a result of this absence, scholars have been encouraged to theorise more broadly about Porter’s working practice than with some other contemporary musical theatre composers. This paper suggests a potential approach for connecting patterns in Porter’s extant lyric drafts and autograph scores that facilitates one means of evaluating his role as composer/lyricist. Drawing on materials from ROSALIE (1937), PANAMA HATTIE (1940), KISS ME, KATE (1948) and SILK STOCKINGS (1955), it considers ongoing questions about authorship and creative authenticity in a collaborative art form while arguing that it is possible to locate Porter’s creativity without exhaustive numbers of scores.

title: Adventures of a Deaf-Mute and Other Short Pieces, by William B. Swett (1860's); Editing & Foreword by Kristen Harmon
summary:
The 10th Volume in the Gallaudet Classics in Deaf Studies Series

In Adventures of a Deaf-Mute, Deaf New Englander William B. Swett recounts his adventures in the White Mountains of New Hampshire in the late 1860s. Given to us in short, energetic episodes, Swett tells daring stories of narrow escapes from death and other perilous experiences during his time as a handyman and guide at the Profile House, a hotel named for the nearby Old Man of the Mountain rock formation. A popular destination, the hotel attracted myriad guests, and Swett’s tales of rugged endurance are accompanied by keen observations of the people he meets.

       Confident in his identity as a Deaf “mute,” he notes with wry humor the varied perceptions of deafness that he encounters. As a signing Deaf person from a prominent multigenerational Deaf family, he counters negative stereotypes with generosity and a smart wit. He takes pride in his physical abilities, which he showcases through various stunts and arduous treks in the wilderness. However, Swett’s writing also reveals a deep awareness of the fragility and precariousness of life. This is a portrait of a man testing his physical and emotional limits, written from the vantage point of someone who is no longer a young man but is still very much in the prime of his life.

       This collection also includes “Mr. Swett and His Diorama,” an article from 1859 in which Swett describes his miniature recreation of the Battle of Lexington, as well as Manual Alphabets, a pamphlet published in 1875 on the history of manual alphabets that includes short biographies of Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet and Laurent Clerc, two pioneers of Deaf education in the United States. The work is accompanied by a new introduction that offers a reflection on Swett’s life and the time in which he lived.

William B. Swett was born in 1824 in Henniker, New Hampshire. He was a carpenter and joiner and an active member of the Boston Deaf-Mutes’ Library Association, the Boston Deaf-Mutes’ Mission, and the New England Gallaudet Association of Deaf Mutes.

title: Caring for our heritage
summary:
FOREWARD
As Chair of Heritage Malta’s Research Committee I feel honoured to have been asked to write the Foreword to this first publication of a collection of research papers showcasing the breadth, and depth, of Heritage Malta’s research interests. These papers were presented during a public seminar held at the Aula Magna of the University of Malta Valletta Campus on 13 September 2013. The very well attended seminar showcased this research to an audience which included scholars, academics, students, Cultural Heritage professionals and interested individuals. This seminar also formed part of the celebrations of the 10th anniversary of the establishment of Heritage Malta as the National Agency for museums, conservation practice and cultural heritage. 

As I had remarked when addressing the closing session of the conference, this was the brainchild of Heritage Malta’s Research Programme Sub-Committee which I chair and which was set up to enable and promote all possible aspects of research related to the sites, museums and collections under the care of Heritage Malta. The members of this sub-committee envisaged this conference as a vehicle for presenting on as wide a scale as possible this sterling work which is not usually much promoted at the local level. The high response generated was however not expected. Although we knew that much sound research was going on, we were extremely pleased to note that so many professional staff were willing to show, explain and discuss the scientific work which goes on quietly but continuously behind the scenes. This is a true reflection of some of the excellent work carried out by Heritage Malta’s dedicated staff.

The nine papers presented in this concise but significant volume ably mirror the previously mentioned wide range of research activities which are a fundamental part of Heritage Malta’s work. They also provide a good insight into the research that goes on behind the walls of museums, archaeological sites, conservation studios and scientific laboratories, which is an essential part of Heritage Malta’s commitment to the preservation of our past, and its presentation to the world at large, with its diverse and multiple audiences, and their varied desires and needs. 
............

It can be concluded that the papers, though at first glance widely different, also have several common threads. They are certainly a window onto the varied and excellent research being carried out across the various Heritage Malta sections and museums, and it is hoped that they will serve as a stimulus to aspiring cultural heritage professionals to develop an interest in these field. They are however also a vivid illustration of the intricate interdisciplinarity which forms the foundation of modern-day conservation and of the importance of ethics and values when preserving and presenting cultural heritage artifacts and sites. These go hand-in-hand with time and patience, as well as discipline, training and research building towards what is today widely considered an important educational and informative area - presenting cultural heritage to the world at large, and preserving it for present and future generations.

I sincerely hope that this compendium of research papers will be read with the same interest and enthusiasm shown by the audience during the conference, and that I myself experienced when helping to edit this book. I conclude by auguring that Heritage Malta will continue to support the sterling research activities of its professional staff, which I hope will also be disseminated in a follow-up volume in the not-so-distant future.


Professor JoAnn Cassar
Chair
Heritage Malta 
Research Programme Sub-Committee

February 2016

title: Eric Ketelaar
The Utilization of Archival Materials in Microeconomic History Research: The Economic History of The Ottoman-Turkey Natural Sea Sponge Gathering Industry.
summary:
Presuming that a certain case study would be presented in line with the utilization of archival materials having various origins, here into this paper, the utilization of the archival sources within the previously completed research works on the Ottoman-Turkey “natural sea sponge gathering” (süngercilik) industry will be presented. Researches on Microeconomic history is known exhibiting a contemporarily advancing trend. Within the mentioned analytical approach to economic history, the leading works refers to the specific production processes, companies and the industrial organizations and in contrary to the more extensive and holistic approaches to the economic history, with their more limited and specific focus, they are mostly presenting findings on the basis of micro scaled economic process. Within the adopted approach as mentioned, these studies exhibit differences with the holistic approaches to history which present the findings of various research undertaken with respect to the main trends of national economies on macro economic basis. The effect of data sources is definitely having an impact on the advancing trend exhibited in the history researches undertaken with a micro economic perspective.  Whereas the observed quality and quantity improvements in essential sources is also becoming the main reason why the gained recognition for the mentioned research agenda is being increasing. On the other end, an important factor effecting their contributions while the number of the likely studies is increasing as mentioned, is the revisions and reconsiderations of the neglected details of the same archival sources which have various origins, and have already been analyzed and examined by the previously completed studies which are mostly known adopting the holistic approaches. (..)

(October, 2015, ongoing paper, submitted to peer review for an International Congress).

Keywords: Micro economic history, Mainstream and institutional economic analysis in micro economic history studies, Archival sources in economic history studies, Archival sources in micro economic history studies.

title: From Rice to Cultural History, via José Nepomuceno
summary: This is a story on how to write and recreate history by using archival research; in re-creating a past, when the past seems to be gone. My first foray into Southeast Asian film research was my work on José Nepomuceno, who was the first Southeast Asian film director and who formed his Malayan Movies in 1917 in the Philippines. None of Nepomuceno’s films have survived, so when I embarked on this research journey I was met with encouragement, but also confusion as to why I wanted to do this and comments that I wasted my time. I wanted to recreate the context in which the films were produced, and understand what impact the films had at the time, who saw them and where they were exhibited.

title: Body of evidence: Reuniting fragments of Cambodian art history
summary: Countless Cambodian sculptures have been damaged and fragmented due to decades of cultural heritage destruction across the country. This article records cases in which a combination of art historical, archival and conservation research has succeeded in recovering and reconstituting works of art, and publicises items that remain incomplete.

title: "Archival Research Processes: A Case for Material Methods"
summary: This article argues for a framework of material methods, a forefronted material-rhetorical approach to archival research, applying material-methodological heuristics of rhetorical accretion and proximity. The article offers an extended example of archival research undertaken at the Public Records Office of Northern Ireland (PRONI). Such heuristic content generated by a material approach is valuable in two ways. First, it offers readable layers of rhetorical accretion that deserve examination and analysis as separate texts in order to make meaning of research processes. Second, such content makes archival methods more transparent while resisting an untroubled narrative arc of our stories of research.

title: An enslaved poet on slavery: a newly discovered 18th-century poem by a man living in slavery
summary: Jupiter Hammon was the first African American writer to publish in America, yet surprisingly little is known about him. We know he was born into slavery on October 17, 1711, and lived on Long Island. There is no record of his mother or father’s identity, nor do we have any physical description of him. Most of what is known about Hammon has come from the remarkable literature he left behind, consisting of four poems and three essays, all published between 1760 and 1787.  But now, with the discovery of the handwritten poem “An Essay on Slavery, with submission to Divine providence, knowing that God Rules over all things,” we have one more document to shed light on the art and thoughts of this unique American writer....

title: Snapping/Snatching Photos in an Indonesian Archive
summary: What to do when you come across "the image" that will make your dissertation argument, that will be on the cover of your book, when reading in an archive where photography of the materials is forbidden? A brief case study for a graduate seminar on the ethics of research.

title: New Research in the diocese of Grosseto: towards a systematic approach in parish research
summary:
"As the chancellor of the curia Francesco Anichini wrote in 1751, the diocese of Grosseto was organised according to the system of parish churches, the only churches where the rite of Baptism could be dispensed, and upon which a series of smaller churches and chapels depended. Anichini was also an accomplished historian, to whom much of the subsequent research and literature on the churches of the diocese of Grosseto is to be credited. However, it is acknowledged that by the time of Anichini much of the archival material pertaining to the diocese was dispersed. Many artworks and artefacts pertaining to local churches were also dispersed, and by the early 20th century, much of the Medieval and Renaissance cultural heritage pertaining to local churches was forgotten.

In this talk archival material that has hitherto received little attention by art historians - such as medieval civic statutes - will be considered in relation to both, local devotional practices and the commissioning of liturgical and decorative works. Newly discovered documents on the diocese of Grosseto will also be discussed alongside previous scholarship on the role that the dominant commune of Siena played in the establishment, decoration and maintenance of these and other local pious institutions. In my contribution I illustrate how these archival resources were unearthed, and how historian and art historians may still provide a significant contribution to knowledge in the area of parish research in southern Tuscany and elsewhere through archival investigation and observation of remaining visual evidence."

title: Deaf American Prose, Vol. 2 (1830-1930)
A decade of creative occupation: The production of a youth arts archive in a hospital site
